Thanks Mark for the comments. However I have a hard time to understand your comments w.r.t layering, and appreciate your clarification. 

1) You mentioned "lower-level code" that only handles interested_parties use case, and what does it do exactly? In the current implementation for interested_parties use case, it just schedules a batch by invoking `grpc_call_start_batch_and_execute` with a callback in grpc closure that gets passed in. 

2) In your comment, you mentioned "CQ" multiple times, and does it refer to the dedicated CQ we created for the CQ use case?

3) In your comment - "it would provide a next() callback that would generate a completion on the CQ", what do you mean by "nex() callback"?

After reading the comments again, I think I have got the general idea and please correct me if I am wrong. 

The "lower-level code" you mentioned is generic in a sense that it will be invoked by both interested_parties and CQ use case. When it is used for CQ use case, the pollset_set that gets passed in corresponds to the dedicated CQ created in CQ use case. Furthermore, we will only invoke `grpc_call_start_batch_and_execute` within the code by passing in different grpc closures for those two use cases (in the current implementation, we have both `grpc_call_start_batch_and_execute` and `grpc_call_start_batch`).

Regarding your detailed comments, I would like to respond to two issues: 

1) `alts_tsi_event` will be different for each batch since its field `send_buffer` will be newly created each time a batch is scheduled. So, after we make `alts_tsi_event` a part of handshaker, we should still  need to initialize the closure each time. 

2) Regarding the test, its sole purpose is to validate the inputs of `grpc_call_start_batch` or `grpc_call_start_batch_and_execute` are correctly populated when scheduling client_start, server_start, and next requests. We do not perform any polling in the test, but to verify the callback and its argument are correctly set in grpc_closure that gets passed to `grpc_call_start_batch_and_execute`. I probably need to create a pollset and add it to the created pollset_set otherwise, it will get failed in ` grpc_channel_create_pollset_set_call`.

> The "lower-level code" you mentioned is generic in a sense that it will be invoked by both interested_parties and CQ use case. When it is used for CQ use case, the pollset_set that gets passed in corresponds to the dedicated CQ created in CQ use case. Furthermore, we will only invoke `grpc_call_start_batch_and_execute` within the code by passing in different grpc closures for those two use cases (in the current implementation, we have both `grpc_call_start_batch_and_execute` and `grpc_call_start_batch`).

Yes, that's exactly what I was suggesting.  The lower level will probably wind up looking something like the code we use to make gRPC calls from within the grpclb LB policy:

https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/lb_policy/grpclb/grpclb.cc#L172

Note that this code very self-contained and does not require a separate event class; it directly owns all of the payload fields (like the send buffer you mentioned) and handles all of the callbacks.

> 1. `alts_tsi_event` will be different for each batch since its field `send_buffer` will be newly created each time a batch is scheduled. So, after we make `alts_tsi_event` a part of handshaker, we should still  need to initialize the closure each time.

I agree that there will be a different send buffer for each message sent.  But since you can only have one send_message batch pending on a given call at a given time, this does not require having a different event object for each batch; you can reuse ther same buffer each time.  There should be no need to re-initialize the closures for each batch.

See the code I referenced above for an example.

Thanks for the confirmation and reference. I have the following question: 

With the above changes you suggested, for CQ use case, do we still need to have a dedicated TSI thread? It looks to me that in CQ use case, gRPC library will handle the invocation of callback (i.e., `alts_tsi_handshaker_handle_response`), and there is no need for TSI thread to do anything. Furthermore, it seems this approach will still work for the Envoy use case without letting it provide any gRPC internal constructs (e.g., `pollset_set`) when creating TSI handshaker. 

If the above claim is true, can we consolidate these two use cases (i.e., CQ and interested_parties) into one? that is to use the `pollset_set` corresponding to the dedicated CQ instead of the one passed in from the caller. Also, we may simplify the code a lot (i.e., `alts_shared_resources`) that handles the coordination between TSI thread and gRPC library. 

If the above claim is false (i.e., we still need a TSI thread), then gRPC library in the callback closure needs to signal the TSI thread to proceed with the result by passing it the closure arg. 

Please let me know what you think.

I did the following quick experiment: for CQ use case, I do not create a dedicated TSI thread, but still pass the "low-level" code the `pollset_set` corresponding to the dedicated CQ. Then, I observed a significant performance regression compared to the case when having a dedicated TSI thread (programs execute successfully in both cases). What confuses me is in the later case, the TSI thread does not seem to do any "MEANINGFUL" work since the callback closure will be invoked by gRPC library but then, I cannot justify the performance boost with the TSI thread.

If you have your own CQ, then you need a separate thread to poll it.  The grpc library will invoke the callbacks when the I/O happens, but the I/O only happens as a result of the polling, and the polling will happen in the thread that's calling the CQ's next() method.  In other words, the callbacks will be invoked by the grpc library, but that will happen in the CQ thread.

The reason it still works without the polling thread is probably because of the client channel's backup poller.  But that will definitely not give you reasonable performance and is not something you should rely on.

Note that you also should not be invoking a callback back into the application code directly from within grpc core.  For the Envoy use-case, you should arrange to return a tag to the CQ when you want to call back into the Envoy code.
